section-block.rac_essential-question: How can we care for our world?

section-block.rac_book_title_byline: Written by Jorge Tetl Argueta, illustrated by Felipe Ugalde Alcántara
section-block.rac_book_summary: A drop of water tells about life as part of the water cycle. The drop travels from Earth to sky and back.

section-block.rac_top-left_header: OUR EARTH | WEEK 4: Protect the Earth

section-block.rac_body-text: Describe for children how water constantly moves in a cycle from inside Earth, to the surface, into the air, and then back to Earth.
Invite children to dance to the PreK On My Way™ theme music to build excitement for learning how to care for the Earth.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read a book called Water, Little Water, written by Jorge Tetl Argueta and illustrated by Felipe Ugalde Alcántara.
Scout loves reading narratives like this one because he learns about how water goes from the Earth to the clouds.
I would like you to think about this question as we read. We will talk about it later. Ready?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the book and the Day 1 prompts. Use Equity Sticks to choose children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What is happening in this picture? What did Little Water change into? Little Water changes into r____ (rain) drops.
section.rac_body-text: At the beginning of the story, Little Water starts as a tiny drop.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Every word has syllables or parts. Let’s count how many syllables the word tiny has: ti-ny. Clap for each syllable.
Drop by tiny drop, Little Water climbs to the Earth’s surface.
How many syllables does the word surface have?
What happens to Little Water in the morning?
Little Water becomes a river, a lake, and what else?
How does Little Water become a cloud? What happens when it falls back to Earth? Show me with your fingers.
Let’s turn and talk about the guiding question:
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk
Then, pick 2–3 children with Equity Sticks to share.
Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: Water can turn into an ocean.

section.rac_body-text: Write and read aloud short sentences about what happens to water from the time it comes from the ground until it gets to the clouds.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Can water turn into a mountain or an ocean?
Water can turn into an o_______ . (ocean)
Water can turn into an ocean.
How does Little Water turn into an ocean?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Children are innately curious about their world. Teaching science in the preschool classroom can help further that curiosity. One practice you can implement to encourage your students’ interest in science is to bring in objects from outside (for example, rocks and sticks) that the children can touch, smell, and otherwise examine.

section-block.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule_day_2: Share the Mind Builder: Persist in Tasks
section-block.rac_body-text: Discuss with children that when they persist in a task, they keep trying even when it is hard. Invite
children to share how they have persisted in the task of learning or doing something, even when it was hard. For example, learning a new word or a new game or tying their shoelaces.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to reread Water, Little Water written by Jorge Tetl Argueta and illustrated by Felipe Ugalde Alcántara.
Clifford knows all about persisting in tasks. He works hard to remember and use the new words he learns every day.

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to the Mind Builder
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s reread the story and think about how the drop of water in Water, Little Water shows the persists in tasks Mind Builder.
section.rac_body-text: Use Equity Sticks during reading to pick children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Little Water has to come from deep in the Earth.
That means Little Water has to go a long way. Let’s imagine what it is like deep in the Earth. How would you feel if you were Little Water? (MB)

Little Water has to keep going even though it’s hard so that he can reach the surface. How does Little Water keep going? How do you keep going when you are doing something hard? You can experiment with different ways that can help you make things easier. (MB)
With every drop, Little Water gets bigger and bigger. First it’s a tiny dew drop, then it becomes a river, and then it becomes an ocean. Show with your arms how big you think an ocean is.
Little Water says “I am all colors and have no color.” What do you think that means?
Drop by drop, Little Water finally turns into a cloud. He made it! What do you think happens next? (MB)

section.rac_body-text: Challenge children to act like drops of water. Create a starting point. Have one child move around the room, and then add one more child each time they reach the starting point. As more children join in, explain how they started with one drop (child) and with each drop the group gets bigger and bigger just like when Little Water started as a dew drop and became an ocean.
Transcribe children’s speech as they talk about why it is important to persist in a task.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Persisting in a task comes naturally to preschoolers, but when the task becomes too challenging, they can get frustrated. When this happens, you can offer a bit of guidance. For example, if a child is having a hard time with a puzzle, you could calmly suggest, Would it help if you turned that piece around? (Young, Reed/NAEYC.org, Oct/Nov 2017)

section-block.rac_top-left_header: OUR EARTH | WEEK 4: Protect the Earth

section-block.rac_body-text: Explain that when a word in English and a word in Spanish sound alike and have the same meaning, we say they are cognates.
Sing about water to the tune of “Twinkle, Twinkle Little Star”: Water, water, little drop, make an ocean, make a lake. . .

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to reread Water, Little Water, written by Jorge Tetl Argueta and illustrated by Felipe Ugalde Alcántara.
Scout likes to read narratives, or stories, that also give information. He is looking forward to learning information about water.
I want you to think about this question as we reread. We will talk about it later:
What do we know about Little Water?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the book and the Day 3 prompts. Use Equity Sticks during reading to choose students to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Little Water passes through tiny holes called pores as it climbs to the surface. Then it gets caught in roots.
Think about what you already know about roots. What do they do with the water that passes through them?
In this picture, we see Little Water as morning dew, resting on leaves.
Have you ever touched dew? What did it feel like?
Drop by drop, Little Water turns into an ocean. If you speak Spanish, the word ocean is océano.
Little Water says, “I am one color in the morning . . .” In English, the word is color, and in Spanish it’s color, too. These words are called cognates.
Look at the picture. Where is Little Water now? What is it doing?
Let’s turn and talk about the guiding question:
What do we know about Little Water?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk.
Choose 2–3 children to share their answers.
Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: Little Water was born deep in the Earth.
Little Water is one color in the morning and another color in the afternoon and at night.
Little Water turns into a cloud.

section.rac_body-text: Share a pen with children as they write together about how water travels from one place to another.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What does Little Water turn into?
Little Water turns into a cl_____ . (cloud)
Little Water turns into a cloud.
How does Little Water turn into a cloud?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Preschoolers are not too young to learn to use cognates. When children have cognate awareness, they will be able to use cognates in their first language to help them understand a second language. You can foster development of this awareness by pointing out cognates when you are reading aloud to students.

section-block.rac_top-left_header: OUR EARTH | Week 4: Protect the Earth

section-block.rac_body-text: Using a globe, point out different countries around the world and explain that people speak different languages around the world.
Sing to the tune of “This Is the Way”: This is the way we care for Earth, care for Earth, care for Earth. This is the way we care for Earth, so we can keep it clean.

section.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule: Share the Big Chart of Big Ideas
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to read You Can Help! It is an informational poster that tells us different ways we can care for Earth.
Scout loves to learn new ways that he can help take care of Earth. He knows how important that is!
Both Water, Little Water and You Can Help! help us understand things about Earth. Let’s see if we can find other connections between the two as we read.
As we read this week’s Big Chart, let’s think about how it connects to this week’s concept question:
How can we care for our world?

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to Protecting the Earth
section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the teacher text from the Big Chart and teach the song. Then use these prompts to discuss the child-facing poster together.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Who can point to the picture of a child turning off a light? Do you turn off the light when you leave the room? Turning off the lights helps Earth.
Which picture shows what we do to use less water? In Water, Little Water, we learned how water moves through Earth and air. How does water move into your house so you can use it?
Who can point to the picture of children recycling? When you recycle, you make sure to separate the different materials into different cans.
How many syllables does the word recycle have?
You can also recycle materials like paper and plastic to make art. Which pictures show recycled art?

section.rac_body-text: Challenge children to play a variation of “Duck, Duck, Goose” called, "Bottle, Bottle, Can.” Follow the instructions for “Duck, Duck, Goose” swapping out the words for “Bottle, Bottle, Can.”
Provide a writing prompt about protecting Earth. Give ongoing feedback as children respond to the prompt.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Children can gain valuable reading comprehension skills when they can make connections between texts. When you read aloud to your students, you can encourage these connections by asking the children questions such as, Does this story remind you of another story we’ve read? and How is this story different from other stories we’ve read?

section-block.rac_top-left_header: OUR EARTH | Week 4: Protect the Earth

section-block.rac_body-text: Remind children about what they read in Water, Little Water about how water goes from a tiny drop to become an ocean. Discuss how the ocean moves in waves. Encourage children to dance as if they were a wave in the ocean. How would they dance if they were a big wave? A small wave?

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to retell and reenact Water, Little Water, written by Jorge Tetl Argueta and illustrated by Felipe Ugalde Alcántara.
Scout likes to learn about how water goes from a tiny drop to a large ocean.
This week we talked about how Little Water traveled from deep in Earth all the way up to the clouds. As we read the book one more time, think about this question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: How does Little Water move from Earth to the sky?

section.rac_body-text: Reread and retell the book together. Use Equity Sticks to pick students to participate in the prompts.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What does Little Water do after it climbs to the surface? Stand up and pretend you are climbing!
Where does Little Water rest when it comes up to the surface? Show me how you would hang on a leaf or a spider web like Little Water.
Before Little Water climbs up to the sky, it becomes a river.
After Little Water becomes a lake, it becomes an ocean.
In Spanish the word ocean is océano. Does anyone remember what word we use to describe when two words in different languages sound alike? They are called c________ (cognates).
Little Water changes color. If you were drawing a picture of water, what color would it be?
Look at the picture. Describe what you see. Pretend you are an animal drinking from the water.
Remember the question I asked before we started to read? Let’s turn and talk and see if we can answer that question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: How does Little Water move from Earth to the sky?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk. Then use Equity Sticks to choose 2 or 3 children to share.
Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: It climbs up to the sky.

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to draw or write about taking care of Earth and to share their work.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Does Little Water climb up to the sky or down to the sea?
Little Water climbs up to the s____ . (sky)
Little Water climbs up to the sky.
What happens to Little Water after it climbs up to the sky?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Gross motor skills are important for children to be able to function independently in daily life, play with their peers, and develop fine motor skills. You can nurture the growth of gross motor skills in your students by incorporating simple games, such as hopscotch and Simon Says, into indoor or outdoor playtime.
